newsitem.title: USA: US Senate tax bill does not touch ethanol subsidy.
newsitem.headline: US Senate tax bill does not touch ethanol subsidy.

text.p: The tax bill proposed by Senate Finance Committee chairman William Roth on Tuesday would maintain the U.S. fuel-tax break for ethanol at its current level, a contrary approach from the House tax-writing panel.
The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill last week to lower the fuel-tax break, now 5.4 cents a gallon, to 5.1 cents and terminate ethonal incentives in 2000.
Ethanol defenders were heartened by the tack taken by Roth, Delaware Republican.
"We've enjoyed a lot stronger support (in the Senate) for ethanol," said a National Corn Growers Association official.

There were, said NCGA official Ellen Dougherty, "reasons to be optimistic in both chambers." She pointed to statements by House Speaker Newt Gingrich, Georgia Republican, in support of ethanol as well as support from farm-state senators.
An eight-page summary of Roth's bill did not mention any attempt to change ethanol provisions nor were there suggestions during a briefing of a desire to change them.
Ethanol accounts for five percent of U.S. corn demand.

Fuel-tax break for ethanol was scheduled to end in 2000. Senate Agriculture Committee chairman Richard Lugar, Indiana Republican, and Senator Dick Durbin, Illinois Democrat, said last week they thought the tax break should be extended.
